s.text: Clinton, in particular, loves this sort of thing as a way of achieving a national goal without costing taxpayers any money.

True, the emphasis of the moment seems to be less on specific services than on a kind of semi-adoption--"mentoring" troubled kids, acting as a role model, and so on--and this kind of service is hard to buy.
(That's why each volunteer "makes a difference," as we are constantly being told.)
In fact, a full-page newspaper ad detailing NBC's abject surrender to the hijacking of all its news shows touts two different interviews with the former general.
In fact, a full-page newspaper ad detailing NBC's abject surrender to the hijacking of all its news shows touts two different interviews with the former general.
Clinton, in particular, loves this sort of thing as a way of achieving a national goal without costing taxpayers any money.
Basically this is the propaganda machinery of war being revved up in peacetime, which is one reason the rhetoric is so overheated and so full of martial metaphors.
And the premise that you must give of your body, not just of your money, makes voluntarism an ideal theme for such an exercise.

And the premise that you must give of your body, not just of your money, makes voluntarism an ideal theme for such an exercise.
In our culture, attitude is easy and sincerity is hard.
